title: r-Uniform Hypergraph
content: An r-uniform hypergraph on vertex set V is a collection of r-element subsets (hyperedges). Every edge has exactly r vertices.

title: Disjoint Edges
content: Two edges are disjoint (independent) if they share no vertices. This is the key notion for matchings in hypergraphs.

title: Hypergraph Matching
content: A matching M in hypergraph H is a set of pairwise disjoint edges from H. Matchings generalize graph matchings to hypergraphs.

title: Matching Number
content: The matching number is the size of the largest matching in the hypergraph. The conjecture asks: how many edges can avoid matching number k?

title: No k-Matching
content: A hypergraph has no k-matching if its matching number is less than k. The function f(n;r,k) maximizes edges subject to this constraint.

title: The Function f(n; r, k)
content: f(n; r, k) is the maximum number of edges in an r-uniform hypergraph on n vertices containing no k pairwise disjoint edges. This is the central quantity.

title: Construction 1
content: Take all r-edges on rk-1 vertices. Since rk-1 < rk, we can't fit k disjoint r-edges. This gives C(rk-1, r) edges with no k-matching.

title: Construction 2
content: Take all edges meeting a fixed (k-1)-set. Any k edges must include two meeting this set, so they share a vertex. Gives C(n,r) - C(n-k+1,r) edges.

title: Conjectured Value
content: The conjecture: f(n;r,k) = max(construction1, construction2). The extremal hypergraph is one of these two constructions.

title: Erdős Matching Conjecture
content: For all r ≥ 3, f(n;r,k) = max(C(rk-1,r), C(n,r)-C(n-k+1,r)). One of the most important open problems in extremal hypergraph theory.

title: Erdős-Gallai (r = 2)
content: For graphs (r = 2), the conjecture is true. This classical 1959 result completely determines when graphs must have k-matchings.

title: Explicit r = 2 Formula
content: f(n; 2, k) = max((k-1)(2k-1), kn - k² - k + 1). The binomial expressions simplify nicely for graphs.

title: Łuczak-Mieczkowska (r = 3)
content: The conjecture holds for 3-uniform hypergraphs. This 2014 breakthrough was the first uniformity beyond graphs to be fully resolved.

title: Kleitman's Result
content: When n = rk exactly, f(rk; r, k) = C(rk-1, r). The first construction is optimal at the boundary case.

title: Huang-Loh-Sudakov
content: For n ≥ 3kr², the conjecture holds. This 2012 result verified the conjecture for 'large n' regime.

title: Frankl Small n
content: For n in range [rk, rk + k/(2r^{2r+1})], the first construction is optimal. Extends Kleitman's boundary case slightly.

title: Frankl Upper Bound
content: f(n; r, k) ≤ (k-1)·C(n-1, r-1). This 1987 bound is always true and is the key tool for proving the conjecture in various regimes.

title: Upper Bound Tightness
content: Construction 2 achieves the Frankl upper bound asymptotically. This shows the bound is essentially tight for large n.

title: Construction 1 Lower Bound
content: f(n; r, k) ≥ C(rk-1, r) whenever n ≥ rk-1. The first construction always provides a valid lower bound.

title: Construction 2 Lower Bound
content: f(n; r, k) ≥ C(n,r) - C(n-k+1,r). The second construction also provides a valid lower bound.

title: Combined Lower Bound
content: f(n; r, k) ≥ max(construction1, construction2). The constructions together show the conjectured value is achievable.

title: f Monotone in n
content: f(n₁; r, k) ≤ f(n₂; r, k) when n₁ ≤ n₂. More vertices allow more edges before forcing a k-matching.

title: f Monotone in k
content: f(n; r, k₁) ≤ f(n; r, k₂) when k₁ ≤ k₂. Larger forbidden matching size allows more edges.

title: Large n: Construction 2 Dominates
content: For sufficiently large n, construction 2 exceeds construction 1. The crossover happens around n ≈ (r+1)k.

title: Asymptotic Behavior
content: f(n; r, k) ~ (k-1)·n^{r-1}/(r-1)! as n → ∞. For large n, the function grows like a polynomial in n of degree r-1.

title: The Open Problem
content: The Erdős Matching Conjecture remains open for r ≥ 4. Proving it would be a major advance in extremal combinatorics.

title: The r = 4 Case
content: The first open case: prove f(n; 4, k) = max(C(4k-1, 4), C(n, 4) - C(n-k+1, 4)). Even this specific case remains unresolved.
